title: 1930s Depression Era Slang
description: Explore the gritty language born from the Great Depression and its hard times

questions.question: During the Great Depression, what was a 'Hooverville'?
options: A shantytown of makeshift shelters built by homeless people
A type of vacuum cleaner factory
A town named after the president

questions.question: In 1930s slang, what was a 'breadline'?
options: A line of people waiting for free food from a charity

questions.question: What did 'riding the rails' mean during the Depression?
options: Illegally hopping on freight trains to travel

questions.question: In 1930s vocabulary, what was a 'soup kitchen'?
options: A place offering free meals to the destitute

questions.question: During the Depression, what was a 'Dust Bowl'?
options: The drought-stricken Great Plains region plagued by dust storms

questions.question: In 1930s slang, what did 'on the dole' mean?
options: Receiving government relief or welfare payments

questions.question: What was a 'hobo jungle' during the Great Depression?
options: A makeshift camp near railroad tracks where hobos gathered

questions.question: In 1930s Depression lingo, what was a 'Hoover blanket'?
options: A newspaper used as a blanket by homeless people

questions.question: What did 'Brother, can you spare a dime?' represent in the 1930s?
options: A popular song and phrase symbolizing the plight of the unemployed

questions.question: In 1930s slang, what was 'scrip'?
options: A certificate or receipt used as a substitute for money

questions.question: What were 'Okies' during the 1930s?
options: Migrant workers from Oklahoma fleeing the Dust Bowl

questions.question: In Depression-era slang, what did 'making do' mean?
options: Getting by with whatever was available

questions.question: What was a 'bank holiday' in the context of the 1930s Depression?
options: A government-ordered temporary closure of all banks
A vacation paid for by a bank
A day off for bank employees

questions.question: In 1930s slang, what was a 'dime-a-dance' establishment?
options: A dance hall where patrons paid ten cents per dance with a partner

questions.question: During the Depression, what did 'Hoover flag' refer to?
options: An empty pocket turned inside out, symbolizing poverty
